intro: Poteranthera calcarata, commonly known as the mountain snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in cool, temperate climates. Its foliage is evergreen, with lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, white pubescence. The flowers, which appear in late spring to early summer, are pale blue to white and are clustered in racemes, adding ornamental value to the plant.
